Message.TypeName: Review SQL queries for security vulnerabilities
Message.Issue: The query string passed to 'MySqlCommand.CommandText.set(string)' in 'DatabaseMgr.AddItem(int, string, decimal, bool)' could contain the following variables 'ZaupShop.Instance.Configuration.Instance.ItemShopTableName', 'name', 'new string[9][5]', 'new string[9][7]'. If any of these variables could come from user input, consider using a stored procedure or a parameterized SQL query instead of building the query with string concatenations.

The query string passed to 'MySqlCommand.CommandText.set(string)' in 'DatabaseMgr.AddItem(int, string, decimal, bool)' could contain the following variables 'ZaupShop.Instance.Configuration.Instance.ItemShopTableName', 'new string[9][3]', 'name', 'new string[9][7]'. If any of these variables could come from user input, consider using a stored procedure or a parameterized SQL query instead of building the query with string concatenations.

Rule.Name: Declare event handlers correctly
Rule.Description: By convention, .NET events have two parameters that specify the event sender and event data. Event handler signatures should follow this form: void MyEventHandler(object sender, EventArgs e). The 'sender' parameter is always of type System.Object, even if it is possible to employ a more specific type. The 'e' parameter is always of type System.EventArgs. Events that do not provide event data should use the System.EventHandler delegate type. Event handlers return void so that they can send each event to multiple target methods. Any value returned by a target would be lost after the first call.
Rule.Resolution: Declare the first parameter of {0} as an object named 'sender'.
Declare the second parameter of {0} as an EventArgs, or an instance of a type that extends EventArgs, named 'e'.
Remove all but the first two parameters of {0}.

Rule.TypeName: Review SQL queries for security vulnerabilities
Rule.Name: Review SQL queries for security vulnerabilities
Rule.Description: A SQL command string built from user input is vulnerable to SQL injection attacks. Microsoft SQL Server and other database servers support stored procedures and parameterized SQL queries, which reduce the risk of injection attacks.
Rule.Resolution: The query string passed to {0} in {1} could contain the following variables {2}. If any of these variables could come from user input, consider using a stored procedure or a parameterized SQL query instead of building the query with string concatenations.
